Comments_List: Had to execute independent research, and then write up and present the results.

I learned about some modeling techniques (from actually doing my thesis), but I didn't learn any skills/insights /knowledge from the meetings of the class or class assignments. 

That only pertains to the class though; my regular meetings with my advisor were incredibly informative and educational.
I learned how to do a research project from start to finish. Asking a question, doing research, analyzing, writing, etc.
I learned how to write a 50+ page paper and how to effectively research and present research to others.
I think the senior essay program was very well structured. I generally enjoyed the weekly meetings although towards the end I sometimes felt like we didn't accomplish much during them.

I think this course met for too long, for too often. It felt like I was scrambling to have some sort of submittable piece of a document for each meeting of the class, but actually doing a research project (or at least, the kind I was doing) doesn't produce work in a steady stream like that. So I ended up spending time each week trying to figure out something to submit for the weekly submission, rather than actually working on my thesis. 

Again, that only pertains to the weekly meeting of the class. The real strength of the Linguistics senior essay is how amazing the advisors are. I essentially had an in-depth class in the topic of my research each week.

fewer course meetings-- the meetings weren't always useful because we met so often (and for so long!)
I think once a week for an hour suffices
It's as good as it needs to be.
It was helpful to have some intermediate deadlines and give each other comments as we wrote.
You'll take it if you need to take it.
Of course I recommend this course if you are a linguistics major! Writing a thesis was a lot of work, but also a lot of fun and incredibly rewarding in the end.
